comments.commentBody: Absolutely and completely untrue, simply an Ivy league sales pitch. Most students that attend public universities can obtain scholarships and grants as good or better than Ivy league schools. My eldest daughter paid absolutely zero tuition for her bachelors at Madison AND her masters at Ann Arbor. Both were for academic merit regardless of income. Schools like MIT and Harvard boast "higher proportion" of students aid simply because the fact is that only the children of billionaires could ever afford to pay 250000 for a bachelors degree. That doesn't mean that those that receive aid are not having to incur crushing debt for the "privileged" of receiving an Ivy education. Even sillier is the fact when Ivy league schools need to fill their myriad of post graduate .student openings the "selections" goes straight out the windows since the openings far exceed the openings, thus being filled by students from all over the world. Even worse is their business schools MBA for which the most rigorous requirement seems to be the ability to pay. Under any close inspection, getting a degree from a much cheaper state institution with a good record is as valuable as one from any Ivy league. In my profession no one has ever asked about where I finished my undergraduate, studies, its just a data point in my resume four lines below where I did my professional training and my work experience. Its as relevant as relevant as the prep school I attended which in the real world no one knows or cares.
The physician is ultimately responsible for the patient's outcome.  It's a tremendous responsibility, one that stays with us after 5pm, and on weekends.

There is some truth to what you're saying, but there's a weird obsession with "fiat" money on the right that goes back as long as I can remember, probably back to when Roosevelt took us off the gold standard if not before. Certain conservatives are obsessed with the idea of fiat money, and the present monetary policy reflects the problems with "fiat" money. Why do you think there are so many gold commercials on outlets catering to conservatives?

The hard thing about conservatives is so many of their ideas are nutty they even realize it, and so they often speak in code which has to be deciphered. Of course their concerns about fiat money reflect their anti-government sentiment. If the government managed all of the gold mines they'd probably be pushing zinc or platinum for money, and be railing against gold.

Just take the cap off of social security and continue taxing income over $117,000.  Additionally, put a "millionaire tax" on individuals making over one million per annum and increase their social security contribution at a higher tax rate for the income over the first million dollars.  Currently, we pay 6.2% and the empoloyer matches with 6.2%.  Income over one million dollars would have no employer contribution but would instead tax the employee 7.0%.  This would keep social security solvent.  It would also discourage employers from overpaying executives since they will continue to pay social security taxes.   As for John Smith, what can I say except I'm certain you were not serious.  The biggest welfare hogs are corporations and the weathy.  What the poor take is a mere pittance in comparison.
Bru, bonus points for Robyn Hitchcock!

Bloody homonyms! I knew I had a phonetic faux pas on my hands as soon as I hit the submit button. YEWS guys don't miss too much here at Wordplay. No need for apology Liz B, indeed I welcome and appreciate your interest.
We-ee-el, on Plant Day, it should be a 'petal' in any case. Don't you think that corolla8s?

SEXTS is a noun. It may have degenerated into a verb along the rubbish strewn information highway. Surprisingly, the emus didn't FLAG it. Deb also seemed to be okay with it. Maybe she rendered them IDLE. The NYT crossword has only used SEXTS in this context once before. It was similarly clued: 'titillating transmissions'. That puzzle appeared on 6/24/11 and was from Milo Beckman. An alternative clue could have been: 'Anthony Weiner's obsession.'

On the lighter side of life, what say we go for a peddle with Robyn Hitchcock and Joe Boyd as they cover a PINK Floyd classic?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FiInEulXXt0

Last TWOSday in July,

Bru

This is from the Harper Collins published World English Dictionary:
sext (sɛkst)

— n
chiefly RC Church the fourth of the seven canonical hours of the divine office or the prayers prescribed for it: originally the sixth hour of the day (noon)
Worthless only in the abstract scientific sense.  I suspect "OKCupid" will find a way to profit from it's findings, if only by modifying a user's visible info in a pseudo-random fashion.
The "changed compatibility" of the "research" has no external validity, so it's pretty much worthless.

OK Cupid scores are not really compatibility scores. They simply score a match between two people in regard to how they answered the same questions. There are hundreds of questions to answer. Some people answer only a few, others answer many. Some have to do with values, some to behaviors, some to general knowledge. As the article points out people get along, or don't, contrary to the scores.

The use of the OK Cupid scores is deceptive, even when not tampered with. OK Cupid's own comments in this article make that clear.

In academia we are required to present our methodology to an Internal Review Board of peers who make sure that the research is ethical and protects subjects. One of the most important principles is "informed consent." Subjects must generally agree to be studied. Obviously these commercial web ventures have no such restrictions. People rail against academic research, but ethical safeguards are very strict in science and social science.

If we privatize everything as Republicans fervently desire, this kind of invasive practice will be more common and no one will have any legal resource to stop it.
I don't understand the outrage - these are *free* websites, folks!  Well, not exactly free - you traded your privacy for your social media and your dignity for your dating service.
I can live without these guys. Some of the music underground can be entertaining. But by and large it's a nuisance.

Times Square has become absolutely menacing with the proliferation of creepy "cartoon" characters extorting money from tourists. Will it take someone to be killed when one of these "things" knocks someone over, presumably by accident, in the crush to get a buck and the "someone" fractures his or her skull?

I don't mind music or performers in the subways on the platforms and walkways.

But when I am held captive on the ride from 42nd St. to 96th St. while first a mariachi band, then a street preacher, then a group of a capella singers and then flying acrobats who can put a foot in my face at any minute all force themselves on me....no.

I gather there are people who enjoy this stuff and that's fine. I'm not Scrooge. It's a big city with some crowded public spaces that need to be shared by all of us--and when I'm held captive I resent it.

I don't want these folks, except perhaps the insane Spidermen and Elmos, put in jail, but a citation or an "adjournment in contemplation of dismissal," yes.
At my daughters school the dorm is empty at thanksgiving. No food service. No nothing. Maybe they can find a friend who will take them in but you can't count on it

Globalization and the consolidation of the commercial real estate industry no doubt reduces the consideration of local context in design.  To me, that is unfortunate.  I'd appreciate more "locatecture" and more consideration of how a building fits in its neighborhood.  Regrettably, the largest projects are more apt to be designed in order to attract multi-national tenants, whose desires may be influenced as much or more by cross-national business needs than by local tradition.
I guess that you haven't listened to Hamas spokespersons.  Their goal is to destroy Israel.  Please be more aware of reality.

Are you aware that Israel left Gaza in 2005? Are you aware that Gaza had vacant farms and money for infrastructure when Israel left? Are you aware that Palestinians in Gaza had access until they started using this access for weapons of war and cement to build tunnels for terrorist acts?

Bandying about the word "oppression" has no substance without facts to back it up. It is a word that is on the list of Hamas talking points for political reasons.

Israel controls airspace, coast and territorial waters, land borders (with Egypt), electromagnetic fields, electricity and fuel supply.  according to the Hague regulations, this constitutes occupation.

The tunnels are part of the struggle of the Palestinians to free themselves from a suppressive occupation of 50 years or more imposed on them by the Israeli's who forced the Palestinians into doing anything they could to try to get free of their oppressors.

The fear of the Israeli's is understandable. They have been brutally oppressing the virtually defenseless Palestinians for over 50 years and it would be a miracle if the Palestinians had not developed a resentment of their occupiers. The real question is why did the Israelis not try to work cooperatively and helpfully with their Palestinian neighbors instead of dominating and oppressing them? For whatever faulty reasoning that impelled Israel to make enemies of the Palestinians, it looks now as if they have dug themselves a deep hole and have no friends around the world except for their special allies in the United States. The only hope for Israel now would seem to be for the zealots to be tamed and removed from leadership and the liberal and peaceful Jews to reassert control and make amends with their Palestinian neighbors.
Great idea and so simple.
Does math create cranks, or merely attract them?

CR, I think this is the sort of thing that a lot of kids - regardless of gender - roll their eyes at, then happily dig out from the closet when needed. It all can go in one or two fairly small cartons, unobtrusive enough - and in my experience, even if there are drug and hardware stores in walking distance (and there aren't, in a lot of instances), when a problem arises, some kids are glad not to have to make the effort.

I recommend a gap year first. My daughter spent a year studying in Israel last year and lived in an apartment provided by her school. She learned to cook and grocery shop for herself, to budget and manage money and to navigate a foreign country in a foreign language(albeit one she'd been learning all her life). Though I know college is different, she's already had a chance to test herself living away from home with others and met that challenge.
Though of course I worry about the new challenges of college, I know she is well equipped to handle all the practical matters, and has confidence in her abilities to do so.

This is exactly how my friends and I went off to college. It never occurred to me to have my mother pack and prepare for me! No need to mooch off others.  Common sense, and an orientation package from the college, told us what we needed.  Maybe the problem with your daughter's friend was not that her parents did not prepare for her move to college, but that they failed (for years) to prepare her to think and plan for herself.

AJ, Ann Landers had a great saying "nobody takes advantage of you without your permission".

And the best prepared among us don't anticipate ever little eventuality. Kids have to fledge out somehow.

I did some of the background work and went to one of the orientations, but when it came down to it, when he moved away to college, was when he got into his car to drive 350 miles there.

There are all kinds of masters at getting others to do their work for them. Some are children who get their parents to do their work for them.  Some are the ones who use the band aids and supplies they don't have because it's so easy to borrow from the prepared.  Some are parents who fall into this trap out of love and care. 'Just sayin.

My advice: Allow your children to become adults.  Don't pack anything for them, don't stress about bedding and first aid supplies.  Send them off and let them deal with whatever challenges college presents.  As a women I would tell my daughters to always stay with at least one girlfriend.  It's was a rule I followed ... I never left a party alone and would never leave a girlfriend at a party. I held onto the rule well into my mid-20s. Drinking, making out, dancing, stupidness occurred but always in the presence of at least one girlfriend.
I found it surprisingly moving - and my kids are 10+ years away from college.

SCD,  for kids who have who have any significant travel, that Thanksgiving break really can be disruptive right at the end of the semester. Kids who remain in campus do seem wistful, but they don't lose momentum like the ones who make significant trips for the long holiday weekend.

Wow, arty,  do you think  you could be even more offensive if you tried a little harder? I find that people who feel a need to disparage others' intelligence often are not nearly as bright as they imagine themselves to be.

The Maginot Line kept the Germans out of NE France, until it was made obsolete in minutes by brilliant moves in 1940. We don't fight wars like that any more, and having bases that encircle a country are useless in modern warfare.

We have 100's of military bases throughout the world. We encircle Russia, and China too. We control almost every major strategic shipping route. We have tens of thousands of troops in live war. We have tens of thousands more dedicated to targeted aerial bombing. We have hundreds of thousands of troops garrisoned outside our borders. What Putin did in the Crimea is like Tuesday afternoon at our beloved Pentagon!

What Putin is doing in east Ukraine is what we're doing in Syria, west Ukraine and dozens of places around the world. We supply Sisi with a modern military so he can crush democracy and imprison Western journalists at his whim. There are plenty of reasons for the world to "sanction" each other. We should resist the temptation because it almost always makes the situation worse.
Great suggestion! simply brilliant.....
You left out "compared to the Soviets", well done.
